claim.text: The modified problems significantly degrade the performance when using implicit reasoning, while the performance of explicit reasoning is always perfect.
claim.exact_quote: From the results in Table 1, we can clearly see\nthat, compare to the original problems, the modified problems significantly degrade the performance when using implicit reasoning. While the\nperformance of explicit reasoning is always perfect.

evidence.evidence_text: In Table 1, the accuracy of implicit reasoning on modified problems is significantly lower than that on original problems, while the accuracy of explicit reasoning on modified problems is always 100%.
evidence.limitations: The results are based on a specific set of modified problems and may not generalize to other types of problems.

evaluation.justification: The evidence from Table 1 strongly supports the claim.
evaluation.key_limitations: The results may not generalize to other types of problems.

claim.text: Implicit reasoning does not follow a step-by-step process but just intuitively thinks of the answer, which makes it less reliable.
claim.exact_quote:
This finding remind us that there
is no free lunch, that is, under current technological conditions, there may not be a perfect solution
that can make LLMs output very few tokens while
keeping the accuracy on solving complex problems.
When you ask LLMs to give the answer directly,
you should know that it has not actually undergone
a real reasoning. Scaling the test-time by using explicit CoT may still be the most feasible method to
further propel the capabilities of LLMs at present.

evidence.evidence_text: The performance of implicit reasoning degrades significantly when the problems are modified to require a step-by-step reasoning process.
evidence.limitations: The evidence is based on a specific set of modified problems and may not generalize to other types of problems.
evidence.exact_quote: From the results in Table 1, we can clearly see\nthat, compare to the original problems, the modified problems significantly degrade the performance when using implicit reasoning. While the\nperformance of explicit reasoning is always perfect.

evaluation.justification: The evidence supports the claim, but it is based on a limited set of problems.
evaluation.key_limitations: The results may not generalize to other types of problems.
